name: ArcheBlade™
description: ArcheBlade is a free to play 3D multiplayer fighting game that captures the essence of combo-based fighting games combined with unique game modes. Play as one of many characters and master your skills to become the best fighter.
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows XP 32bit Processor:Intel Core 2 Duo 1.86 GHz, AMD Athlon 64 X2 2GHz Memory:2 GB RAM Graphics:ATI HD3850, GTX250 DirectX®:9.0c Hard Drive:1500 MB HD space Other Requirements:Broadband Internet connection
recommended_requirements: OS:Windows 7 32/64bit Processor:Intel Core i3 3GHz, AMD Phenom II X2 3GHz Memory:4 GB RAM Graphics:ATI HD4870, GTX460 DirectX®:9.0c Hard Drive:1500 MB HD space Other Requirements:Broadband Internet connection

It's like a real Multiplayer Online Battle Arena! It's not Aeon of Strife which DotA and League of Legends are based off of. It is a legitimate online action brawler.  Archeblade is still very much in development, in the process of continually improving itself for an enjoyable game. The developers like to be involved with the community to help this process, whether it be for buffs and nerfs or general suggestions.  I think it's a great game with a lot of potential behind it. It's free to play, so give it a swing. Also remember, this game is STILL IN DEVELOPMENT. So if you have problems or suggestions to report, it is recommended to post in the Archeblade Community Hub for any constructive feedback and suggestions. As well as general solving of problems.

I have to say, it's been a while since a game captured my attention like this one. While it's somewhat easy to pick up, it takes a lot of time to master.  The gameplay, controls, are simple on the surface, but to really learn the ins and outs of how to actually play the game takes a lot of time and experience. So, if you are not willing to spend that time, you're going to get pummelled by those who have spent the time...  ...because the combat in this game is, for the most part, all about timing. Yes, there's some relatively simple combos which you can learn fairly easily, and there's not a whole lot of depth to that part. No, the challenge is in learning when each character's vulnerability periods are in their moves, and learning when you should or should not use a move, and when you can take advantage of another character's vulnerable periods.  As mentioned, the controls are relatively simple. Standard FPS-style WASD+mouse type movement, jump, two attack buttons (being mouse L and mouse R), guard, dash, reload (which only is used in a few characters), two special skills, and a power attack modifier. Your basic attacks are made with your attack buttons, and hitting an attack button during the animation of a previous attack can chain an additional attack to it... the concept behind most basic combos. What will/will not chain depends on the character, though there are some which are universal, eg. L mouse attack followed by R mouse attack, which follows up the first hit with a knock-up move, allowing further comboing subsequently.  Aside from that, there's a rage bar that builds up from hitting/being hit, which after having a sufficient amount, you can use to execute your special skills. There's also the stamina bar, which is used up when you dash, but slowly regenerates over time. Using the power attack modifier (which is allowed at certain points in certain combos) allows you to enhance specific moves, such as a guard breaker or adding a knockup to a regular non-knockup move, but consumes stamina (though once upon a time it used to be rage).  Each attack animation though, has its own wind-up and wind-down delays, which leave you vulnerable to being hit yourself since you cannot interrupt the animation while it's in progress. Hence, the key to winning fights in this game is taking advantage of the opponent's vulnerable timings while avoiding leaving yourself vulnerable. And this is what takes time and experience to learn, and it's not something that you're going to pick up your first hour in the game. It will take a lot of lost battles while you learn, 'Okay, if I do this move, it leaves me open to being hit if it doesn't connect or they block it,' etc.  My first few hours in the game during the beta period, I was often up against people who had played hundreds of hours in the beta before, and it was a struggle to get a hit in at all against many of these players, and every opening I left was exploited. So, you learn not to leave the openings, and where the openings are that you can take advantage of. And when you're up against multiple opponents, you not only have to worry about the one person you're up against at the time, but that someone else might hit you from behind while you're trying to execute a particular combo.  Which brings me to what some consider a flaw in the combo system, that the combos are not particularly intricate or varied. If Archeblade was solely a 1 vs 1 game, I would agree. However, Archeblade is a team game for the most part, and the idea of combos being a focus is sort of a hard thing to implement in such an environment, because multiple players participating in a battle means that you're not likely to be free to finish off a big combo chain in any case. So while the fighting game enthusiast in me bemoans the lack of combos as such, the nature of the game sort of means that you can't really do a whole lot of them to begin with... I honestly don't know if there is a way to make the two integrate.  About character balance... quite frankly, it reminds me of fighting games, where some characters are easy to pick up, may have 'cheap'er tactics they can use, and certain characters will have certain advantages over other characters. But in my limited experience with barely 90 hours in the game, it seems to me that given that the nature of winning a 1 vs 1 fight is more about play/counterplay and mindgames, it's still pretty good for balance. Throw that all into a team play environment though, and such arguments should honestly become moot, since the goal then becomes to help the team win, and diverse roles where characters can complement each other become an advantage. Then again, true to the state of many multiplayer team games, you always have (too many) people who are focusing on getting kills rather than helping the team win, so they complain about the little imbalances...  Okay, enough about the gameplay.  Graphics: Nothing special, modelling and texturing are decent. Effects are not too flashy so that they are overwhelming, which I appreciate, because too much flash can become distracting and take away from awareness in a battle. Animations are well done, smooth and natural looking. Art design's well done overall and has some decent variation, but not completely to my tastes... more on that later.  Audio: Some of the one-liners from the characters are cheesy. Sound effects are fitting, and do their job well. Music is well done, but may or may not be to everyone's stylistic preferences, being a bit of a mix between a contemporary orchestral style with rock and electronic, mostly up-tempo as tends to be found in fighting games. The amount and variety of music though is sadly limited though, so while I had the music playing for the first 20 or 30 hours of the game, after that I turned it off and played whatever I felt like in the background instead, though every now and then I'd turn it on just to hear it, since the music isn't bad, just too short.  Network: This game seems to lack retroactive hit detection or any kind of latency compensation. So, it plays much like games in the early days of internet gaming in that you have to lead your  fire swing in the place that your target will be, rather than where they are currently on your screen at the moment. This is not a deal-breaker for me, having learned long ago how to play with this kind of lag, but I know some players have been quite vocal about the game being too hard to play without a sub-100ms ping. Nevermind that from where I am, most servers end up ~200-300ms, and I still think it's playable with some learning to adjust.  Issues with packet loss over the network or possibly server-side slowdown are likely responsible for some of the 'rubber-banding' issues which you sometimes run into, but I cannot confirm the technical issues with that, only that it makes sense logically from past experience with networking and online games.  Complaints: No deal breakers for me, but definitely some annoyances.  1. Minimum player limit for a map to start. And while you're waiting, you're stuck in the lobby... you can do nothing but chat. A more polished solution would be to let people run around inside the map, practice movements or fights, but not have the actual game/scoring active. Switch teams (if applicable), autobalancing, etc. during this time as well. Once the minimum requirements for the game to start are met, everyone is killed so they all respawn at the same time, and then the match can begin.  2. Outfits, specifically the gals. Renoah's the only one that comes with a default outfit that's got decent coverage. Ended up getting the alternate skin for Valle just so she could wear a proper dress! Well, at least they don't limit skin showing to the females exclusively.  Overall: Fun game, have enjoyed playing it a lot, and hope to continue to playing it for some time still. Too bad Codebrush didn't succeed financially with it.

So I went into this game completely blind, and I've gotta say, overall I'm impressed.  Archeblade is a Free To Play, online Third Person Brawler. With a character system similar to League Of Legends (minus the free rotation system), and gameplay which I imagine is a dumbed-down version of the niche title, Anarchy Reigns (although honestly I've never played it, but I imagine it's similar; so take this with twelve metric tons of salt). The game starts you off with enough 'currency' to buy up to two different characters. As all characters are priced the same, you can pick the two you like (I'd reccomend picking two characters that are distinct from one another though so you can get used to a variety of different playstyles).   You must purchase a character before you can play. However, the game does a poor job of explaining this.   After playing the (optional) tutorial as a character named Valle - some form of blonde Valkyrie wielding a giant hammer - I was given a free 7 Gems (paid currency; hardly enough to get you anything). I then noticed a Training mode on the main menu. This mode allowed me to try any character I want against a couple of static bots. Useful for figuring out combos, both listed and unlisted (and by unlisted I just mean attacks that recover quick enough to be chained) and how a character feels in general.  I recomend you try out every character in this mode before purchasing your first two characters.   My first match was a Free-For-All match, in which I had chosen Elika, a gun-toting, tan, dark elf lady with a bountiful chest, lucious legs and a  booty fo' dayz . She's kinda ugly, but I can see the appeal. She mows down her foes using a series of kicks and gun-fu; VERY reminicent of Bayonetta. The game is very quick to pick up provided you're observant and already used to similar third-person brawlers (i.e., Dynasty Warriors experience will transfer a little bit here). Characters control using 6 buttons (not including WASD), for:  <> A light attack - Standard; leads into a combo of some sorts <> A heavy attack - Can be any number of things; for Elika, it's a forward sliding kick that is followed up with a backwards dash and two gunshots, for Valle it's a series of 360-degree hammer spins. Can also be comboed with light attacks for unique moves. <> A special move - Default keybinding is shift; again, this can be any number of things. For Elika it was a backstep, for Valle it was a forward dash. Costs stamina. <> Jumping - Characters can use their light or heavy attacks while in mid-air. <> Power Charge - Holding the ALT Key will change the properties of some moves in exchange for stamina usage. Some moves become capable of breaking guard, others do more damage, some even gain 'super armor', which prevents the character from flinching (similar to it's usage in fighting games, but not exact) <> Skill Buttons - Every character has two skills which cost RP gauge segements to use (RP being gained on-hit and being hit) [/list] The controls are quite intuitive, in my opinion, and responsive too (all my actions are done with purpose; I rarely misclick ).  Talking outside my first match or two, I've come to the conclusion that the characters are fairly balanced for the most part, with no characters outright dominating the field (however, there are cheap characters - looking at you, Renoah and Hyde). One issue I have though is that the characters all appear to be balanced for duels, rather than teamfights. This leads to some AoE buffs becoming stupidly strong when stacked (for example, Valle's regeneration), or duplicates of the same character in a fight becoming too strong as they can cover for eachother's weaknesses). There is also an issue with juggling, as once you are knocked up in the air, successive hits from any source will keep you up there. This means that if you're laid into by multiple enemies at once, and they get past your guard, it's likely you'll die unless you have an ability that actively prevents it, such as DanMei's temporary invlunerability, or Renny's teleport. In duels though, juggling is much harder to pull off, and can only be done effectively with a few characters (others are just better set using their other comboes). There are also some issues with hitboxes and animations. My best example would have to be DanMei, whose light attacks are far lunging. However, due to his large size and his melee attack's lunge, it is needlessly hard to hit targets that are at point blank as you can easily overshoot.  After poppin' some caps in foo's heads with my gun-fu, I came close to the top of the scoreboard on my first match. Unfortunately, I earned a meager amount of meceta (money) for my win (I earned around 70; characters cost 1400 each, and items can range from 800 to over 5000).   ...this brings me onto the subject of 'items'. In Archeblade you can kit out your character in all sorts of tacky, cool or cute looking gear. This gear affects the stats of you character, and can change all sorts of things, from armor, to attack damage/range. Unfortunately, there are items that are  exclusive  to the paid curency, Gems.  HOWEVER , before you stop reading this review, turn 360 degrees and nope out of this store page/community. The stat boosts on these items are not outright insurmountable. As the bulk of fights come down to user skill and error (rarely will that extra 5 speed units or 240 HP make a difference in a lot of situations). It's a horrible practice, but one that I, personally am willing to overlook  temporarily  because I enjoy the gameplay enough. I do sincerely hope the developers will rethink their business approach in the near future though. Else I fear for this game's future (and my playtime).   As of the 12th of May, 2014, the developers have officially stopped supporting this game. In light of this,  they have removed the stats from all gear in the shop . In a way, this is great, because now experienced players cannot have any statistical advantage over newbies. Fights are now PURELY skill-based. The downside is that there will be no more updates. Offical servers are also gone, but users can host their own ones.   To sum this game up:   Genre:  Third-person Brawler  Balance:  Good outside of teamfights - Only decent in them  Grind:  Considerably long unless you focus all your money on kitting out a single character. Pricing and meceta gain rates need adjusting. However, upon leveling up you get an extra 200 meceta, so that can speed you along a bit, especially at the earlier levels.  Learning Curve:  Moderate - Very low if you have decent prior experience with third-person brawlers.   Pay2Win?:  In the literal sense, yes. However, the advantages are not end-all and can easily be circumvented if you're a more skilled player.   Pretty?:  Boobs, butts, thighs, abbs. Many of the character designs are quite sexualized. If you're the kind of person who legitimately believes that 'trigger words' are a thing in written text, or tells people to check a privilege of some sorts. This game might not be for you.  No, I was talking about the game in general:  Eh, it's passable. Characters are a tad too differnt in theme, but are distinct enough that you can recognize them at a glance and are interesting to look at. Environments are generic and expected from a game of korean heritage, but not ugly.  Is it worth a go? Yes. Especially since the PC scene has been starved of games from this genre as of late.

Let me start by saying: THIS IS NOT A P2W GAME.  Now that's done, this game is a really fun and addicting fighting game based on your actual skill. The store items, wich can be bought with real or in-game money dont ad that many stats, so there is not an item that will make you OP, making the game a skill based game.  Pros: -Good Music. -Good Graphics (Anime art style). -Easy to learn.  -Every character is different from any other character and every single one of them has a unique role in team gameplay. -Wide range of matches, from 1 vs 1 to 7 vs 7 (including Deathmatch, TDM, Capture point and Round Match) -Includes a Host Server exe so you can play with your friends in private.  Cons: -There is no match making. You simply enter a server and if you're lucky its almost full. -You need to stay in the lobby and wait for everyone to be 'locked' wich means that in a 5 vs 5 match you need to wait for 5 people in both teams to be ready and actually start playing. -Servers lag a lot. Even the server with lower ping have lag spikes from time to time. -Every character needs to be bought for you to play with. They give you 3000 game money, enough to buy 2 characters (1400 each). -There is very few maps and two of them are actually bugged. -There is a character called Renoah (sniper) that has a unfair and OP ultimate that takes almost half the amount of hp every enemie has.   Rate: 7/10 The server and match making need to be improved a lot.

AB is a fun game. The community is decent, the mechanics are interesting, and the soundtrack is alright.   The game(like all fighting games) will need balance patches, new characters, etc. etc., but as a whole I feel like it is a worthwhile venture for people's time.   Takes a bit of skill to get into, but a little bit of practice goes a long way (no i'm not talking about that 5 hour combo memorization that fighting games require, I'm talking about learning when to guard, when to attack, and when to use abilities).   Since pretty much the only game to ever do what AB did with even the smallest success was Anarchy Reigns and that bombed, I'd give AB a chance while it's still around.  Devs don't make these games very often, so a decent one is a 'GEM' of sorts.

For a small company to release a game such as this is huge!! This game does need some improvements, but that is expected. People that are bashing this game because they think a champion is OP need to get there head checked. Game Balance come with patches and seeing champion stats on a large scale can provide this information. It's very difficult for game dev's to make a completely balanced game with just a small beta or in house testing.   As far as bugs and gliches there are not many and I don't know if you have ever played an EA game on release, but they are all terrible and rarely work properly until days/weeks later. I give mad props to Codebrush for creating this game. I have already played abour 5 hours and have had a blast.   Pros   - Unique Champions to choose from  - Multiple Game Types/Maps  - Fun Competitive Gameplay  - Training allows you try champions before you buy  - Seems like the Devs care about the community  - Boobs  Cons   - Pain to find/join servers  - Account/Menus/Shop could be more intiutive  - No ranked play (yet)   @Codebrush - Things I think should be improved to make your game better and more profitable.      -- Big Enhancements --  - Queue System - Having to find and locate a server is a pain (Seperated by regions/gametype) - Ranked Play - Create a ranking system similar to Starcraft 2, Leage of Legends, or Dota 2. - Shop - Everything should be purchasable with enough gameplay. Making items that affect stats only purchasable with real money is a terrible idea (this is why 95% of FTP games never get a large playerbase). You will still make money I promise! People don't mind spending money if they think the game is being fair to everyone. **Note I have spent $20 on your starter pack - Release New Champions to play with on a monthly/bi-monthly basis     -- Small Enhancements --  - At the end of a match if enough people click restart match; It should just restart not kick you back to the menu. - Combine Gear Up/Account Info/Items/Leaderboard into one easy to use Account page. - Allow players to set the difficulty of the bots in training.  All in all I think the game has promise and plan to have some fun playing it the months/years to come. I hope codebrush continues to patch and development the game to make it as succussful as possible.   -Dank

It's not real often that I can find a game that really captures my interest for an extended period of time, but this one has. It's now Free to Play (optional $10 all-access pack) so there's no reason not to try it. It's entirely PvP but well balanced. You can literally take any given character and become amazing with it based on your personal level of skill. It's not a 'this one characer or class beats all' kind of game. It rewards a fast reaction time and ability to learn a person's pattern's & behaviors with a character. If you can do these two things you'll be extremely great at the game. Each character has a strength and weakness that can be played upon and knowing each character's abilities and limitations helps greatly in battle. There's not so many maps to choose from, but this is made up for by really great gameplay.
The game itself may look appealing but overall wasn't that good in terms of gameplay.

One map, I cannot recall the name has 2 connecting bridges that allow you to 'sneak' across and cap your enemies crystal base/altar. Even though its awful overall, there are a few good points.  Easy to earn in-game currency (sorta).  Easy to pick up and play. I'm afraid I don't have much love for this game. While in combat, I had serious issues trying to land any hits on my opponent. The lack of a targeting system keeps you on your toes to try and hit your opponent before they move out of your line of action. Because of that, slower characters are always at a disadvantage and quicker characters can be difficult to play due to the intense sensitivity. In the public games, 9 out of 10 times the games were seriously mismatched. At a starting level, I was pitted against level 20's and 30's on my first playthrough. Also, many times the teams were unbalanced, leaving one side to always be the winner. One final mention is that several times I found myself choosing one character, and being thrown into the area with a completely different one. There needs to be some serious adjustments made, in my opinion, as I really do want to like this game, but can't at its current state.

I would love to be able to recommend this game, I really would, but I can't. I started off thinking it would be some sort of moba similar to Awesomenauts only 3D and with some cool Skullgirls style combat, but I was sadly mistaken. The game is filled with mainly useless characters who don't really fit to the block, bait, and hit from behind play style this game has. Also there seems to be some sort of large gap in skill, as they let new players mix in with people much higher levels than them. The combat seems to follow this same pattern every time of just blocking and then unblocking to hit a player from behind. This seems kind of easy to do right? With some characters, yes they move fast in a straightish path and can do this easy. Others can't do this at all. My first character had two pistols and it seemed cool at first until you realize everyone wants to go do their own thing and you are left defenseless. I bought a melee character because they give you enough in game money to get two characters to start off with. This is when I really started to notice how much the camera fights you when you are attacking. It was just dreadful. Every time you attack the damn thing starts moving in all directions and it just made the whole experience harder. I loved the concept of a moba based on fighting games, I think the intro video on the company's website used Street Fighter as an example, but yeah, it was just not there. The game needs to work itself out a little bit and comeback with a more balanced roster and a way better camera.

This game had a lot of potential at the time. It's fun, but the thing that everyone seemed to have complained about Pay to Win (P2W). I started to think this is true. When they had the old starter kit you started with all this armory that gave you an upper edge. I understand it's something that gives the player something for being supportive, but it didn't need to give the player so much to start with. There were two ways to pay for armor real money so you can buy tokens, and in-game money that you get for each match depending how well you did. Tokens had the potential to get you the item sooner that the in-game money. That was something I thought was pretty good.  The servers were possibly the worse of this game. For me living in the western part of the US I can still get pings in most games under 60, but when it comes to this game. I'm lucky enough to get one that is remotely close to 70. The servers had the worst ping reading and made it almost impossible to play.   The gameplay is really simple. Move click click dodge dodge. Just a regular beatem up style game, but there's one flaw to this. The range attacks. I can see that they wanted to touch on all aspects and classes as much as possible, but when it came to players using just one button it made the game completely boring. I don't remember that Ice girl's name I used, but her and very very few characters were actually somewhat balanced. The characters that can go strictly range made the game boring since you move as fast going backwards as you do going forward. The characters that had a roundhouse attack which I think only one did at the time I played players abused it alot. Abilities like that needed to have a strict cooldown so players didn't resort to just that.   The game has a lot of unique characters and some I never thought I would see. The game kept you wanting to play, but due to it's lack of support from the developers after seeing how things were getting abused and how servers didn't meet up to par with ping. I'm not kidding, more than 90% of the servers they had weren't even populated so there was no need for them. Certain Characters overpowered the other characters. Players relied on one move to win them the game with no mix ups. I spent a lot of time in the training sessions for every character before picking my first one and let me tell you Archeblade players:   Every character has combos if you can't land them then try to approach them differently.   My Ice character was a short melee player which can dish out a lot of damage. I spent time on her the most and won a lot of matches against players who were supposedly title 'Pay 2 Win players' It's a challenge but it's not impossible.   Gearing up wasn't really too bad. Obtaining gear required 2 steps.  1) Get to the level required to unlock it 2) Have enough money to purchase it (Tokens or In-game)  Step one didn't have a problem to it. It was just the money part. Matches didn't give you a lot even if you win the match. This was a flaw mistake made by developers which I think was something they thought of to get players to buy the starter kit rather than waste the time getting beat up from other players who were higher skilled than them. That's not how you draw a crowd to play your game. It's like putting a band-aid on the player for them giving you $20 and holding their hand through everything. That doesn't teach the player only gives them the thought that if they just cough up the money they can have whatever they want.  Gaming isn't like that. Call of Duty, Halo, Super Smash Bros. All these games have something unique and every player new or veteran have to learn new things bring up new tactics against other players. Archeblade had that going for it, but the way you obtain gear from not getting enough money and players just having enough and buy the kit gives them the wrong mind set. As a developer you should listen to your community, but not to a point where you give them everything they want.  This brings up another argument. As developers you guys refused to listen to your community. Even when there was video evidence over unbalanced content. That's what disappointed me the most getting shut out by the people who brought a great game and watching it fall with the team. I may not be a developer, but I know that if you screw up on a game and not listen to your community you are going to start losing them one after another.  The team has then separated and they are under a new team. Whether they still have license to Archeblade is beyond me. I recommend this game to give it a chance, but I don't recommend to those who believe in Pay to Win parts of games.   Developers if you read this I want you to understand I played this game for 5 months even though my time playing it over all is 10 hours that was because I was trying to find matches to play in each day and server pings were really bad, and the reason Archeblade failed wasn't because of financial reasons it was because you guys didn't want to listen to us. Archeblade is a Free-To-Play 3rd person multiplayer action game that tries to pull off the idea of a multiplayer Devil May Cry, does it succeed? Not exactly. The concept of the game is to play in team vs team multiplayer matches and buy new characters with your in-game currency (like League of Legends for example) And the modes consist of your standard Deathmatch modes and Point Domination modes. The characters vary from strong brutes to fast assassin types and each character has several moves to choose from. The problem with the game though isnt so much the concept as it is the execution, since it suffers from performance issues, confusing interfaces and flat out boring combat. While it does have some good things going for it, it has an overall and overwhelming blandness to it that prevents it from reaching a wider audience.  THE GOOD: > Character designs are interesting > Moves look cool > Can sometimes be fun > Scantily clad female characters are R34 waiting to happen  THE BAD: > Latency & Performance issues > Lack of players > Absolutely no feeling of weapon impact, and no hitsounds either. > Gravity has characters jumping as if they were on the moon. > Characters take longer to unlock than youre probably willing to play. > Unshakable feeling of dullness and boredom > Developers supposedly abandoned the game. > TERRIBLE DIALOGUE & VOICE ACTING.  THE UGLY: Not even the half-naked elf-girl wizards of this game can save it. And i think that was this games trump card.  BOTTOM LINE: Unless you REALLY have nothing else to play, there are SO many better options. I cant imagine anyone playing this for too long unless youre a desperate anime fan or new to computer games.  Not recommended 3/10

You will love this game. You will love it enough to completely loathe it. Here's why.  I've been playing Arche Blade for a few hours now, and when I first picked it up and started playing the tutorial and training mode, I was absolutely immersed in the action combat system. It's something that will remind you both of Dark Souls and Smite.  The problem is that it's also got some elements of an early 2000's first person shooter- that is, the games modes are centered on deathmatches and point control, which, don't get me wrong, is incredibly fun. But only for so long. I find myself thinking that this game would be a fantastic action game for the next generation of F2P multiplayer battle games. If you've heard of Gigantic (an upcoming action game by Motiga), it'll feel something like that. If you haven't heard of it, definitely look it up.  The game also uses an old school server list system instead of the now integral 'Play Now' button you find in most mobas and team fighting games today. This isn't necessarily an issue, but it lends itself to the problems that result from server lists. This would include having too many players, not enough players, not being matched with players by ELO and instead just hoping you get a good match, etc.  The characters are balanced enough to play the game, but you'll definitely run into some games that you're raving about how OP the healer character can be. (Wtf!?).  You can also play the same character as other people on your team- something you can't do in MOBAs for this exact reason: your team comp will either become completely OP, or complete trash. You can modify your server to remove this feature, but most servers don't do so.   Oh, and I forgot just one thing. There are instances in the game where a skilled player can fire off a combo to knock you up (which prevents you from doing anything to attack or defend yourself) and repeatedly *keep* knocking you up without ever getting a chance to save yourself. It's extremely annoying and unfair.   This could easily be an MLG E-Sport to contend with the next generation of team based fighters. But the devs have basically left it as it is and refused to update it for months at a time. That's why I can't recommend this game.
